730684f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Entrance to Brooklyn Bridge in 1857.]
730684f.text:
"Entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge in 1857" p.227
Pelletreau, William S.
Early New York houses with historical-genealogical notes. New York; Francis P. Harper, 1900.

730663f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730663f-a.text:
A general view westward from the Brooklyn Bridge (under construction), over the Cherry Hill section, Printing House Square, City Hall Commons and westward to the Hudson (North) River. Shown in the foreground, is the Manhattan abutment of the bridge, with the Roosevelt Street Ferry to Broadway, Brooklyn adjoining. Points of interest shown are, U.S. Post Office,
Tribune Building, Harper's and the Newsboy's Home.
About 1870-1875.
Brown Brothers.
Published in the American on December 1906, and the New York Times
of October 20, 1912.

730664f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730664f-a.text:
A general view westward from the incompleted Brooklyn Bridge. In the background is the North (Hudson) River and its far Jersey shore. Silhouetted against same are the Post Office and the
Tribune building.
1876
American Studio
Gift of Urbrock Collection

730665f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730665f-a.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construction, with the "Catwalk" and Manhattan anchorage in the foreground. Also shown is a general view westward over the City Hall and Printing House Square area, to the Hudson River, with its Jersey shore line just beyond. Note how the U.S. Post Office and the Tribune Buildings predominated at this date.
About 1878-1879.
Ewing Galloway.

730667f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge, while under construction.]
730667f-b.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construction and showing the stone supports and cable, prior to the laying of the cat walk. This view is northeastward from Manhattan and shows the Brooklyn shore in the background. Note the masted schooners in the foreground on the South Street waterfront.
About 1880.
Gift of H.D. Jewett.

Two additional views of the same structure; one of which is similar in direction to the above, the other being photographed from Brooklyn.
About 1880
Gift of George T. Bagoe
No. 86 Madison Avenue.

730667f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge, while under construction.]
730667f-a.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construction and showing the stone supports and cable, prior to the laying of the cat walk. This view is northeastward from Manhattan and shows the Brooklyn shore in the background. Note the masted schooners in the foreground on the South Street waterfront.
About 1880.
Gift of H.D. Jewett.

Two additional views of the same structure; one of which is similar in direction to the above, the other being photographed from Brooklyn.
About 1880
Gift of George T. Bagoe
No. 86 Madison Avenue.

730666f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan end of the bridge, while under construction.]
730666f.text:
(1)
Manhattan end of Brooklyn Bridge, while under construction.
About 1880.
(2)
The same, another view.  About 1880.

730673f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the sightseeing public walking the length of Brooklyn Bridge during its construction.]
730673f.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: An early view, taken in 1884.
1884

730671f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the sightseeing public walking the length of Brooklyn Bridge during its construction.]
730671f-a.text:
(1)
Throngs of sight-seeing public visited the Brooklyn Bridge, to walk its length during its construction, and especially after its completion. The then marvel of engineering, was continually thronged with large crowds, as the view shows.
About 1884.
Eugcne L. Armbruster, Collection.
(2)
The same; a later positive copy.
About 1884.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

730672f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the sightseeing public walking the length of Brooklyn Bridge during its construction.]
730672f.text:
(3)
The same; a later negative copy.
About 1884.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

730678f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan end of the bridge.]
730678f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A view of the Manhattan end, with its train shed.  Note the cables used for the train propulsion on the bridge incline.  Prominently shown, is the dome of the Pulitzer (World) Building, with the spire of the Tribune Building southward.

About 1890.

Brown Bothers.

Neg.# 2998

730676f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [East River - Manhattan.]
730676f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge, viewed southwestward from Brooklyn and showing same spanning the East River to Manhattan. Underneath the bedway, in the center, is the financial district with the spire of Trinity Church predominating. Outstanding at the right is the distinctive Tribune Building.
About 1890
Mildenburg, photo
P. L. Sperr Collection

730677f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the Swamp, an area populated by leather tanners.]
730677f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge, viewed northeastward from Manhattan and showing this engineering triumph spanning the East River to Brooklyn. In the foreground is the locality, better known as "The Swamp," an area populated by leather tanners.
About 1890
Mildenburg, photo
P. L. Sperr Collection

730679f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan - East River - Brooklyn.]
730679f-a.text:
(1)
Brooklyn Bridge, as seen from the Manhattan side, looking east to Brooklyn.
About 1890.
(2)
Atop the Brooklyn Bridge, looking west along the pedestrian
walk.
About 1890.
Gubelman

730679f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan - East River - Brooklyn.]
730679f-b.text:
(1)
Brooklyn Bridge, as seen from the Manhattan side, looking east to Brooklyn.
About 1890.
(2)
Atop the Brooklyn Bridge, looking west along the pedestrian
walk.
About 1890.
Gubelman

730681f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan - East River - Brooklyn.]
730681f.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A general view southward from same. Downtown Manhattan is on the right; Bedloes Island and its Statue of Liberty in the center and Governors Island (with its rotund "Castle William') to the left. In the foreground is a ferry boat preparing to dock at the ferry house at the foot of Fulton Street, Brooklyn.
1894
J. S. Johnston, photo
Copyright 1894
Ewing Galloway

730682f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730682f.text:
53-63 Park Row, (Pulitzer or World Building), at the N. E. corner of Frankfort Street, showing a general view eastward of the Brooklyn Bridge, environs, the East River and the Brooklyn shore. The foreground area is the industrial section popularily known as the "Swamp." Dominant there is the 10-story Healy Building and the Shot Tower. The former is at Gold and Ferry Streets, while the latter is at Cliff and Beekman Streets. Thru the left midground runs Cherry Street, a one time fashionable
thoroughfare that parallels the water front.
1894
J. S. Johnston photo
Copyright 1894
Ewing Galloway

730680f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan - East River - Brooklyn.]
730680f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge as viewed northeastward from Manhattan and showing same spanning the East River to Brooklyn.
About 1893
J.S. Johnston, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

730734f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge spanning the East River between Manhattan and Brooklyn.]

730735f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge spanning the East River between Manhattan and Brooklyn.]

730746f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge over East River, as it stretches from Brooklyn to Manhattan.]

730689f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge from Manhattan.]
730689f-a.text: Brooklyn Bridge, as seen from Manhattan. The same view, from a further point.

730691f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Midstream on the East River.]
730691f-a.text:
(1)
Majestic Brooklyn Bridge, as seen from one of the then taller buildings in Printing House Square, looking northeast.
About 1900.
. Gray.
(2)
The same, as seen from the East River, south from Brooklyn Bridge,
in mid-stream.
About 1900.

730686f.text:
(1)
Pedestrian walk of Brooklyn Bridge.

W. Gray.  No REraoDUCrIoas. NegetwNoi1
(2)

About 1900.

730687f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan approach.]
730687f-a.text:
Manhattan approach on the Brooklyn Bridge, looking west from the New
York pier of the bridge.
About 1900.
Gubelman.

730688f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Harbor traffic.]
730688f-b.text:
(1)
Harbor traffic of a proud metropolis, passing underneath Brooklyn Bridge.
About 1900.
Gubelman.(t)

(2)
Similar scene, showing S.S. 'City of Boston' passing underneath
Brooklyn Bridge.
About 1900.
Gubelman

730690f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge, as seen fren Brooklya.
Abeut 1900.
Brooklyn Brige, as seen fron South Ferry, in Manhattan.
Abeut 1900.
Gubelman.

730694f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Fulton Fish Market.]
730694f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A northeastward view across and showing this structure spanning the East River between the Fulton Fish Market district
Manhattan and Brooklyn (background).
About 1910.
Wurts Brothers.
(Not a dry mount item).
rla w 4s4

730695f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [view showing lower Manhattan].
730695f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge, and the downtown Manhattan skyline, as seen fron the Brooklyn side and viewing southwestward on the East River, Prominently showu, from left to right are, the Woolworth, Singer, Equitable, and the Bankers
Teust Co. Buildings.
About 1920.
Ewing Galloway.

730696f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge over East River, connecting Manhattan to Brooklyn.]

730698f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan Bridge.]
730698f-a.text: The Brooklyn Bridge with Manhattan Bridge in the rear. May 1924. Ewing Galloway, Photographers

730700f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan Bridge - East River.]
730700f-a.text:
(1) Brooklyn Bridge in foreground, followed by Manhattan Bridge, shown
spanning the East River.
July 1925.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Same.
August 1925.
P. L. Sperr.

730700f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan Bridge - East River.]
730700f-b.text:
(1) Brooklyn Bridge in foreground, followed by Manhattan Bridge, shown
spanning the East River.

730699f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - Manhattan Bridge - [painters on the Brooklyn Bridge].
730699f-a.text:
The Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges, as seen from the Manhattan side of the East River, and viewing eastward to Brooklyn. Note the painters giving
the Brooklyn Bridge its annual protecting coat.
About 1925.
Ewing Galloway.

730704f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [looking towards lower Manhattan from Brooklyn].
730704f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: The financial district of lower Manhattan as viewed in a southwestward direction from Brooklyn and under the Brooklyn Bridge. The prominent building shown is the 70-storied structure of the Bank of
Manhattan Company.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.
(Not a dry mount item).

730703f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge, spanning the East River between Manhattan and Brooklyn.]

730717f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730717f-a.text:
(1).  Brooklyn Bridge (suspension); beginning at Centre Street and Park Row, facing City Hall Park, in Manhattan, and terminating in Brooklyn at Fulton and MSands Streets. Actual work was begun in January, 1870 and it was completed in May, 1884, having been opened in the previous year. Its overall length is 1; miles, width 85 feet, with a central snan across the East River, 1595 feet long and 135 feet above high water mark. John A. Roebling, who drew urthe snecifications an d bepan construction was succeeded upon his death by his son, Washington A. 'oebling. Being the first bridge to connect Manhattan and Brooklyn, it acquired a colorful history and world-wide fame as a wonder of modern engineering and human endeavor. ( see: Moses King, Handbook of New York Cit (1892).)
June 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

730717f-c.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730717f-c.text:
(1).  Brooklyn Bridge (suspension); beginning at Centre Street and Park Row, facing City Hall Park, in Manhattan, and terminating in Brooklyn at Fulton and MSands Streets. Actual work was begun in January, 1870 and it was completed in May, 1884, having been opened in the previous year. Its overall length is 1; miles, width 85 feet, with a central snan across the East River, 1595 feet long and 135 feet above high water mark. John A. Roebling, who drew urthe snecifications an d bepan construction was succeeded upon his death by his son, Washington A. 'oebling. Being the first bridge to connect Manhattan and Brooklyn, it acquired a colorful history and world-wide fame as a wonder of modern engineering and human endeavor. ( see: Moses King, Handbook of New York Cit (1892).)
June 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

730731f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - Manhattan approach.
730731f-a.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge and it's Manhattan approach as viewed eastward from the Municipal Building. This crosses the East River to the Brooklyn locale between the Columbia Heights area (right) and Flatbush Awenue Extension (left, approach to the Manhattan Bridge). The foreground zone has at times been known as the "Swamp' and"Cherry Hill'.
April 1940
George D. Chinn

PROE BROOKLLYN TO NEw YORE --S TODAY A D YESTERDAY
Two views of the world famous Brooklyn Bridge as it stretches from Brooklyn to Manhatten. Compare the two, one made today andthe other "many, many years ago", and note thedrastic changes that have taken place.
Phote by Underwood and Underwood  N.D.
